hero.title: Diet & Nutrition: Choosing the Right Food
hero.subtitle: Why I do not recommend domestically produced rat pellets; which commercial diets are relatively trustworthy; and the practical value and limitations of the Shunamite Diet mixing system.

body.text: Choosing What to Feed

At the current stage, I do not recommend any form or brand of domestically produced compound (pelleted) diets for fancy rats. I sincerely hope that one day a truly trustworthy, rat-specific diet will be developed locally, but unfortunately, as things stand, that product does not yet exist.
Why I Do Not Recommend Domestic Rat Pellets

In today’s pet food market, manufacturers that conduct systematic research specifically focused on the nutritional needs of fancy rats are almost nonexistent. Even when a product provides a so-called “nutritional analysis,” it usually remains at a very superficial level, such as crude protein and fat percentages.

What is seriously lacking is a deeper breakdown of rodent-specific requirements, including the structure of protein sources (animal versus plant origin and specific amino acid needs), the composition of essential fatty acids, the bioavailability of trace elements and vitamins, and the differing nutritional priorities across life stages (juvenile, adult, senior, and breeding).

A more practical issue lies in production economics. Building a dedicated production line for an exotic pet such as fancy rats requires substantial investment. Meanwhile, overall awareness of small-animal welfare remains limited, and the number of owners willing to invest long-term time and money into learning about rat nutrition is relatively small. In such a market environment, few companies are willing to take on what is almost guaranteed to be a loss.

As a result, what we commonly see are so-called “rat pellets” that are in fact produced on low-cost dog or cat food lines, or even based on outdated formulations that no longer meet modern canine or feline nutritional standards.
These low-cost compound feeds often struggle to meet even basic dog or cat requirements, let alone the needs of rats—small mammals with fast metabolisms and far more complex dietary structures.
Are There Any Compound Diets That Can Be Trusted?
Yes—but very few.

At present, I only recommend a small number of well-established, long-term validated imported diets: Oxbow juvenile/adult rat diets, Science Selective rat diets, Mazuri rat diets, Rodent Origins, and Versele-Laga rat diets. Beyond these, I do not recommend other products.

It should be noted that due to import costs, regulatory barriers, and in some cases indirect distribution channels, these diets are undeniably expensive. For multi-rat households or ratteries, this often represents a significant and ongoing financial burden.
Is There a More Scientific and Cost-Effective Alternative?
Yes—and it is a very mature approach, provided you are willing to learn and take a hands-on role.

What I am referring to is the Shunamite Diet mixed-feeding philosophy, widely used internationally and developed by Alison Campbell. This is not a simple “recipe,” but a complete, flexible dietary system that relies on observation and adjustment.

Alison consolidated many years of hands-on experience and extensive cross-disciplinary discussion into the book *The New Scuttling Gourmet*. At 432 pages, it covers nearly all of the core issues related to fancy rat nutrition.
What Practical Value Does This System Have for You?

It clearly explains how to select ingredients for mixed diets, how to classify them scientifically, and how to determine appropriate volume ratios between categories. It addresses nutritional priorities for different life stages and physiological states, links changes in behavior, coat quality, or body condition to possible deficiencies, and even suggests ingredients for so-called “herbal mixes,” allowing rats a degree of self-regulation.

If you have the time, I strongly recommend reading the original book. It enables you to adjust ingredients and proportions based on real-world observation rather than relying on rigid, experience-based assumptions.
If you are not yet able to commit to a deep reading, you can still begin by learning the essential principles of mixed feeding through the educational content on my website.

Once you genuinely understand and master the logic behind mixed feeding, even with diverse and high-quality ingredients, it is entirely possible to keep costs at around 20 CNY per half-kilogram. In practice, you will find that this is already a very high mixed-diet cost—yet it remains lower than nearly all commercial rat pellets while approaching an ideal nutritional state.
Do Not Turn the Shunamite Philosophy into a Formula
I frequently observe a common and potentially dangerous tendency: oversimplifying Alison’s philosophy into fixed formulas, such as rigid percentage breakdowns. This approach is not advisable.

The core of the Shunamite Diet has never been about fixed ratios. It is a dynamic, adjustable, individual-centered feeding system. Its real value lies in allowing you to modify ingredients and proportions in response to age, health status, activity level, and breeding demands, rather than being constrained by formulas that merely appear scientific.
Does Mixed Feeding Have No Drawbacks?

It does have drawbacks—quite a few, in fact—but in my view they are currently acceptable. Unlike compound diets, mixed feeding cannot guarantee that every bite contains an identical nutrient profile. Differences in intake speed and ingredient choice between individuals are inevitable.

However, by offering a sufficiently wide variety of ingredients and reducing the relative weight of any single component, these effects can be minimized. This also lowers the nutritional risks associated with selective eating or competition, as missed nutrients from one ingredient can be compensated by others.

More importantly, this approach offers additional benefits: it dramatically improves dietary enrichment, allowing rats to gain exploration and enjoyment from the act of eating itself—an experience that no form of compound diet, including compressed pellet mixes, can provide.
Adopting Alison’s mixed-diet approach means preparing a wide range of ingredients: multiple grains, diverse animal protein sources, diverse plant protein sources, and many other supplementary items.

These ingredients are often not fully used in a single batch, and consumption rates vary, creating a risk of spoilage. When keeping only a small number of rats with low turnover, I recommend finding a reliable “larger group.”
This group may be a trusted rattery or equally responsible friends, allowing you to purchase ingredients jointly and mix diets together so that supplies are used more quickly and waste is reduced.
A Final Note: Mixing Diets Is Hard Work and Requires Responsibility

Preparing mixed diets is time-consuming, labor-intensive, and demands a high level of responsibility. If someone takes on this work for you, they deserve appropriate financial or moral support. Accounting only for ingredient costs while ignoring the labor involved is inherently unfair.
